facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 387 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 387 of 1961. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 29, 1960, of the Labour Court, Meerut in case No. 1 of 1960.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 29, 1960, of the Labour Court, Meerut in case No. 1 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 29, 1960, of the Labour Court, Meerut in case No. 1 of 1960. C. Misra, for the appellant. Ranganadham Chetty, A. V. Rangam, A. Vedavalli and P. C. Agarwala, for the respondent. 1962. March. 6.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on March 6, 1962 by WANCHOO, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. March. 6. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO, J.- This appeal by special leave raises the question of interpretation of s. 6-E,  2  b  of the United Provinces Industrial Disputes Act, U.P. Act No. XXVIII of 1947  hereinafter called the P. Act , which is in exactly the same terms as s. 33  2  b  of the Industrial Dispute, Act., No. XIV of 1947,  hereinafter referred to as the Act , as amended by Act 36 of 1956.

facts.text: Appellant is a Strawboard Mill.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a Strawboard Mill. The respondent was in the employ of the appellant. On August 12, 1959, the respondent was given certain orders by the Technical Director of the appellant, but he refused to companyply with them.

facts.text: Respondent was in the employ of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was in the employ of the appellant. On August 12, 1959, the respondent was given certain orders by the Technical Director of the appellant, but he refused to companyply with them. The same day the respondent refused to companyply with certain similar orders given by the machine-man.

facts.text: On August 12, 1959, respondent refused orders by Technical Director.

anchor.surface_text: On August 12, 1959, the respondent was given certain orders by the Technical Director of the appellant, but he refused to companyply with them. The same day the respondent refused to companyply with certain similar orders given by the machine-man.

facts.text: On August 12, 1959, respondent refused similar orders by machine-man.

anchor.surface_text: The same day the respondent refused to companyply with certain similar orders given by the machine-man. Again on August 13, 1959, he refused to obey similar orders of the shift in-charge. Finally, on August 14, he refused to obey similar orders of another shift in-charge.

facts.text: On August 13, 1959, respondent refused orders by shift in-charge.

anchor.surface_text: Again on August 13, 1959, he refused to obey similar orders of the shift in-charge. Finally, on August 14, he refused to obey similar orders of another shift in-charge. Consequently a numberice was served on the respondent to show cause why he ,should number be dealt with under cl. 22 a  of the Standing Orders which provided that wilful insubordination or disobedience of any lawful orders of superior was misconduct.

facts.text: On August 14, 1959, respondent refused orders by another shift in-charge.

anchor.surface_text: Finally, on August 14, he refused to obey similar orders of another shift in-charge. Consequently a numberice was served on the respondent to show cause why he ,should number be dealt with under cl. 22 a  of the Standing Orders which provided that wilful insubordination or disobedience of any lawful orders of superior was misconduct.

facts.text: Show cause notice served on respondent under cl. 22(a) of Standing Orders for wilful insubordination.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently a numberice was served on the respondent to show cause why he ,should number be dealt with under cl. 22 a  of the Standing Orders which provided that wilful insubordination or disobedience of any lawful orders of superior was misconduct. The respondent submitted his explanation.

facts.text: Respondent submitted explanation to show cause notice.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent submitted his explanation. He was then suspended and a charge-sheet was served on him on August 16, 1959. Thereafter an inquiry was held into the alleged misconduct.

facts.text: Respondent suspended and charge-sheet served on August 16, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: He was then suspended and a charge-sheet was served on him on August 16, 1959. Thereafter an inquiry was held into the alleged misconduct. After the inquiry was over the appellant referred the matter for the decision of the Labour Commissioner without giving any prior decision of its own as provided in cl. 30 of the Standing Orders.

facts.text: Inquiry held into alleged misconduct.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter an inquiry was held into the alleged misconduct. After the inquiry was over the appellant referred the matter for the decision of the Labour Commissioner without giving any prior decision of its own as provided in cl. 30 of the Standing Orders.

facts.text: Appellant referred matter to Labour Commissioner per cl.30 Standing Orders without own decision.

anchor.surface_text: After the inquiry was over the appellant referred the matter for the decision of the Labour Commissioner without giving any prior decision of its own as provided in cl. 30 of the Standing Orders. The Labour Commission, however, refused to give a decision and informed the appellant that it companyld take such action as it was entitled to under the Standing Orders.

facts.text: Labour Commissioner refused to give decision, directed appellant to take action under Standing Orders.

anchor.surface_text: The Labour Commission, however, refused to give a decision and informed the appellant that it companyld take such action as it was entitled to under the Standing Orders. The appellant again approached the Labour Commissioner for giving an order as envisaged by cl. 30 of the Standing Orders, but the Labour Commissioner finally refused to pass any order and directed the appellant to take such action as it thought fit and as was within its power.

facts.text: Appellant dismissed respondent on February 1, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the appellant dismissed the respondent on February 1, 1960. As however, two disputes were pending between the appellant and its workmen one before the Industrial Tribunal No. 3. at Allahabad and the other before the Labour Court at Meerut, the appellant sent applications by post on the same day to the two authorities for approval of the action taken, namely, the dismissal of the respondent.

facts.text: Two disputes pending: one before Industrial Tribunal No.3 at Allahabad, other before Labour Court at Meerut.

anchor.surface_text: As however, two disputes were pending between the appellant and its workmen one before the Industrial Tribunal No. 3. at Allahabad and the other before the Labour Court at Meerut, the appellant sent applications by post on the same day to the two authorities for approval of the action taken, namely, the dismissal of the respondent.

facts.text: Appellant sent applications by post on February 1, 1960 to both authorities for approval of dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant sent applications by post on the same day to the two authorities for approval of the action taken, namely, the dismissal of the respondent. It appears that the tribunal at Allahabad approved of the action on March 22, 1960.

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal at Allahabad approved action on March 22, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the tribunal at Allahabad approved of the action on March 22, 1960. When however the same matter came before the labour companyrt at Meerut on April 29, 1960, it refused to approve the action taken, even though the order passed by the tribunal at Allahabad already was brought to its numberice.

facts.text: Labour Court at Meerut refused approval on April 29, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: When however the same matter came before the labour companyrt at Meerut on April 29, 1960, it refused to approve the action taken, even though the order passed by the tribunal at Allahabad already was brought to its numberice.

facts.text: Labour Court held appellant not motivated by victimisation.

anchor.surface_text: The labour companyrt at Meerut held that the appellant was number motivated by victimisation. It further held that in the inquiry held by the appellant, prima facie case had been made out for the dismissal of the respondent but the labour companyrt said that though ordinarily the application of the appellant should have been granted in these circumstances it refused to approve the dismissal on the around that the application for approval had been made after the respondent had already been dimissed therefore it held that the application was number bona fide

facts.text: Labour Court held prima facie case made out in inquiry for dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: It further held that in the inquiry held by the appellant, prima facie case had been made out for the dismissal of the respondent but the labour companyrt said that though ordinarily the application of the appellant should have been granted in these circumstances it refused to approve the dismissal

facts.text: Labour Court refused approval because application made after dismissal, not bona fide.

anchor.surface_text: it refused to approve the dismissal on the around that the application for approval had been made after the respondent had already been dimissed therefore it held that the application was number bona fide and in the circum- stances the prayer that the order of dismissal should be approved was number granted.

facts.text: Appellant obtained special leave from Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the appellant obtained special leave from this Court and that is how the matter has companye up before us.

facts.text: Application to Meerut received on February 3, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The application at Meerut was received on February 3 and the application at Allahabad on February 4, 1960. In these circumstances we are of opinion that the appellant had made the application to the tribunal simultaneously and without delay on its passing the order of dismissal and its action was therefore in accordance with the proviso.

facts.text: Application to Allahabad received on February 4, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: the application at Allahabad on February 4, 1960. In these circumstances we are of opinion that the appellant had made the application to the tribunal simultaneously and without delay on its passing the order of dismissal and its action was therefore in accordance with the proviso.

facts.text: Supreme Court allows appeal, sets aside Labour Court order, approves dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: This being the only point on which the labour companyrt had refused to give approval, the appeal must succeed. We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the order of the labour companyrt and approve the action taken by the appellant.

Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 29, 1960, of the Labour Court, Meerut in case No. 1 of 1960. C. Misra, for the appellant. Ranganadham Chetty, A. V. Rangam, A. Vedavalli and P. C. Agarwala, for the respondent. 1962. March. 6.

This appeal by special leave raises the question of interpretation of s. 6-E,  2  b  of the United Provinces Industrial Disputes Act, U.P. Act No. XXVIII of 1947  hereinafter called the P. Act , which is in exactly the same terms as s. 33  2  b  of the Industrial Dispute, Act., No. XIV of 1947,  hereinafter referred to as the Act , as amended by Act 36 of 1956.
Thereupon the appellant obtained special leave from this Court and that is how the matter has companye up before us.

interpretation of s. 6-E,  2  b  of the United Provinces Industrial Disputes Act, U.P. Act No. XXVIII of 1947  hereinafter called the P. Act , which is in exactly the same terms as s. 33  2  b  of the Industrial Dispute, Act., No. XIV of 1947,  hereinafter referred to as the Act , as amended by Act 36 of 1956. The question arises in this way. The appellant is a Strawboard Mill. The respondent was in the employ of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: We shall therefore set out the provisions of s. 33  2  which reads as below - During the pendency of any such proceeding in respect of an industrial dispute, the employer way, in accordance with the standing orders applicable to a workman companycerned in such dispute-  a   b  for any misconduct number companynected with the dispute, discharge or punish, whether by dismissal or otherwise, that workman Provided that numbersuch workman shall be discharged or dismissed, unless he has been paid wages for one month and an application has been made by the employer to the authority before which the proceeding is pending for approval of the action taken by the employer.

concepts.interpretation: Action taken means actual dismissal, application after but simultaneous with dismissal and wage payment

anchor.surface_text: Sub- section  1  refers to matters companynected with a dispute which might be pending and forbids any alteration to the prejudice of the workmen companycerned in such dispute, in the companyditions of service applicable to them immediately before the companymencement of the industrial proceedings resulting from such dispute and also forbids the employer from discharging or punishing any workman whether by dismissal or otherwise in companynection with any matter companynected with the dispute

This view has been followed by the Gujarat High Court... With respect we feel that it is number necessary to read the words action taken in the proviso as equal to action proposed to be taken... and that the apparent companyflict between the two parts of the proviso can be harmonised, as we have indicated above

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave raises the question of interpretation of s. 6-E,  2  b  of the United Provinces Industrial Disputes Act, U.P. Act No. XXVIII of 1947  hereinafter called the P. Act , which is

issues.text: interpretation of the terms of s. 33(2)

anchor.surface_text: The question thus raised depends upon the interpretation of the terms of s. 6E  2  which as we have said already correspond word for word with the provisions of s. 33  2  of the Act. We shall therefore set

issues.text: interpretation of the proviso to cl. (b)

anchor.surface_text: We are concerned in the present appeal with the interpretation of the proviso to cl.  b  which says that no such workman shall be discharged or dismissed, unless he has been paid wages for one month and

issues.text: whether applications have to be made, where more than one dispute is pending before more than one tribunal, to all the tribunals where the disputes are pending or whether an application to only one of them would be enough

anchor.surface_text: It is unnecessary to consider in the present case whether applications have to be made, where more than one dispute is pending before more than one tribunal, to all the tribunals where the disputes are pend

anchor.surface_text: The next question is as to when should an application be made. In this connection our attention was drawn to s. 33-A of the Act which gives a right to the employer to apply for redress in case an emp

arguments.claim: The proviso to s.6E(2)(b) requires application for approval before dismissal; post-dismissal application is not bona fide

anchor.surface_text: it refused to approve the dismissal on the around that the application for approval had been made after the respondent had already been dimissed therefore it held that the application was number bona fide and in the circum- stances the prayer that the order of dismissal should be approved was number granted.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: . 289. A.I.R. 1961 Guj, 22, make an application to the authority companycerned for approval of the a

arguments.court_reasoning: View that application must be made before dismissal is not correct; plain meaning allows post-dismissal but simultaneous application

arguments.claim: No motivation by victimisation and prima facie case made out for dismissal in inquiry

anchor.surface_text: When however the same matter came before the labour court at Meerut on April 29, 1960, it refused to approve the action taken, even though the order passed by the tribunal at Allahabad already was brought to its notice. The labour court at Meerut held that the appellant was not motivated by victimisation.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: red to pay the necessary wages and at the same time sent the application by post to the tribunal companycerned for approval of the action taken by it.

arguments.court_reasoning: Only point of refusal was timing of application

arguments.claim: 'Action taken' in proviso means 'action proposed to be taken'; requires prior approval before dismissal

anchor.surface_text: It has been urged on behalf of the respondent that the words action taken in this part of the proviso mean the action proposed to be taken and therefore all that the employer can do is to make an application to the tribunal asking it to approve the. action proposed to be taken by it

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the dispute pending before the tribunal but such discharge or dismissal is subject to the proviso, which imposes certain companyditions on it. The int

arguments.court_reasoning: Would make no difference between s.33(1) and s.33(2)(b); against purpose of 1956 amendment; against rules of interpretation to add words

arguments.claim: Proviso allows employer to dismiss first then apply for approval of action taken

anchor.surface_text: We are however of opinion that on this interpretation there would really be no difference between sub-s. 2 and sub-s. 1 of s.33 and the intention of the legislature in making the amendment in 1956 would be rendered nugatory.

arguments.claim: Plain meaning of proviso gives employer power to discharge or dismiss before obtaining approval

anchor.surface_text: Moreover, it is against the rules of interpretation to add words to a provision, when the provision, as it stands, is capable of a reasonable meaning which will give effect to the intention of the legislature even on the words as they stand.

arguments.claim: Form K under r.60 supports that application is for approval of action already taken

anchor.surface_text: This is borne out by form K under r. 60 of the Rules framed under the Act which corresponds to form XV under r. 31 of the U.P. Rules.

arguments.claim: Use of 'approval' suggests approval of something already done, not proposed

anchor.surface_text: Further the use of the word approval in the proviso also suggests that something has been done by the employer who seeks approval of that from the tribunal.

arguments.claim: Language different from s.33(1) and (3) which require 'express permission' prior

anchor.surface_text: If the intention was that in view of the proviso the employer could not pass the order of dismissal or discharge without first obtaining the approval of the tribunal, we see no reason why the words in the proviso should not have been similar to those sub-ss. 1 and 3

arguments.claim: If no approval, dismissal falls; workman deemed never dismissed; protects via s.33A

anchor.surface_text: If the tribunal does not approve of the action taken by the employer, the result would be that the action taken by him would fall and thereupon the workman would be deemed never to have been dismissed or discharged

arguments.claim: Proviso requires dismissal, wage payment, and application to be simultaneous parts of same transaction

anchor.surface_text: As we read the proviso, we are of opinion that it contemplates the three things mentioned therein, namely, i dismissal or discharge, ii payments of wages and iii making of ,an application for approval, to be simultaneous

arguments.claim: Proviso interpretation must not whittle down protection in s.33A

anchor.surface_text: there is no doubt that the proviso to s. 33 2 , b should be so interpreted as not to whittle down the protection provided by s. 33-A.

arguments.claim: Bombay HC view in Premier Automobiles erroneous; no need to read 'action taken' as 'proposed'

anchor.surface_text: With respect we feel that it is not necessary to read the words action taken in the proviso as equal to action proposed to be taken... and that the apparent conflict between the two parts of the proviso can be harmonised

arguments.claim: Calcutta HC in Metal Press Works correct: payment and application simultaneous with dismissal, reasonably

anchor.surface_text: The contrary view has been taken by the Calcutta High Court in Metal Press Works Limited v. Deb R. 1 where it has been held that payment of wages and the making of the application should be simultaneous with the order of discharge or dismissal.

arguments.claim: Appellant complied: applications sent same day by post as part of same transaction, without delay

anchor.surface_text: The application at Meerut was received on February 3 and the application at Allahabad on February 4, 1960. In these circumstances we are of opinion that the appellant had made the application to the tribunal simultaneously and without delay

holdings.text: The proviso to s.33(2)(b) permits the employer to discharge or dismiss a workman for misconduct unconnected with the pending dispute before obtaining approval, provided wages for one month are tendered and an application for approval of the action taken is made to the authority as part of the same transaction.

anchor.surface_text: Moreover, it is against the rules of interpretation to add words to a provision, when the provision, as it stands, is capable of a reasonable meaning which will give effect to the intention of the legislature even on the words as they stand. On the plain meaning of the proviso, it is clear that it gives the employer the power to discharge or dismiss the employee before obtaining the approval of the tribunal concerned but at the same time the protection afforded to the employee by the proviso has to remain effective. It seems to us therefore that when the proviso speaks of an application for approval of the action taken, the action taken there is the order of actual discharge or dismissal made by the employer and it is for the approval of this order that the application is to be made.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain textual meaning of 'action taken' and 'approval'; distinguishes from s.33(1) requiring prior permission; supported by Form K, purpose of 1956 amendment freeing employer for unconnected matters; rejects adding 'proposed'; harmonises with s.33A.

holdings.text: Tendering wages for one month to the workman satisfies the payment condition in the proviso, even if refused.

anchor.surface_text: It is not disputed before us that when the proviso lays down the condition as to payment of one months wages, all that the employer is required to do in order to carry out that condition is to tender the wages to the employee. But if the employee chooses not to accept the wages, he cannot come forward and say that there has been no payment of wages to him by the employer.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Logical necessity to prevent workman frustrating provision by refusal; ordinary meaning of 'paid'.

holdings.text: If the authority does not approve the action taken, the dismissal or discharge falls and the workman is deemed never to have been dismissed or discharged, continuing in service without need for specific reinstatement provision.

anchor.surface_text: If the tribunal does not approve of the action taken by the employer, the result would be that the action taken by him would fall and thereupon the workman would be deemed never to have been dismissed or discharged and would remain in the service of the employer.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Logical consequence of non-approval; protects workman via s.33A if contravention; order not final until approved.

holdings.text: The three requirements of the provisodismissal, tender of wages, and application for approvalmust be simultaneous parts of the same transaction, done immediately and without delay, reasonably interpreted based on facts.

anchor.surface_text: As we read the proviso, we are of opinion that it contemplates the three things mentioned therein, namely, (i) dismissal or discharge, (ii) payments of wages and (iii) making of ,an application for approval, to be simultaneous and to be part of the same transaction, so that the employer when he takes action under s. 33 (2) by dismissing or discharging an employee, should immediately pay him or offer to pay him wages for one month and also make an application to the tribunal for approval at the same time.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonises proviso parts without rewriting; ensures s.33A protection not whittled down; factual determination per case.

holdings.text: Sending applications by post on the same day as dismissal to both authorities constitutes making the application simultaneously and without delay, in accordance with the proviso.

anchor.surface_text: The application at Meerut was received on February 3 and the application at Allahabad on February 4, 1960. In these circumstances we are of opinion that the appellant had made the application to the tribunal simultaneously and without delay on its passing the order of dismissal and its action was therefore in accordance with the proviso.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts show same-day posting despite distances; reasonable timing, not split-second.

holdings.text: The Labour Court's view that the proviso requires application for approval before dismissal, rendering post-dismissal application not bona fide, is incorrect.

anchor.surface_text: The view taken by the labour court that the application must be made before dismissing the respondent is not correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contradicts plain meaning and scheme of s.33(2)(b).

holdings.text: s.6-E(2)(b) of U.P. Industrial Disputes Act is to be interpreted identically to s.33(2)(b) of Industrial Disputes Act.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave raises the question of interpretation of s. 6-E,  2  b  of the United Provinces Industrial Disputes Act, U.P. Act No. XXVIII of 1947  hereinafter called the P. Act , which is in exactly the same terms as s. 33  2  b  of the Industrial Dispute, Act., No. XIV of 1947,  hereinafter referred to as the Act , as amended by Act 36 of 1956.

holdings.text: The appeal is allowed; order of Labour Court at Meerut set aside; action of dismissal by appellant approved.

anchor.surface_text: This being the only point on which the labour court had refused to give approval, the appeal must succeed. We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the order of the labour court and approve the action taken by the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Compliance with proviso established; sole ground of refusal erroneous.

holdings.text: No need to decide whether applications must be made to all tribunals when multiple proceedings pending, as applications were made to both here.

anchor.surface_text: It is unnecessary to consider in the present case whether applications have to be made, where more than one dispute is pending before more than one tribunal, to all the tribunals where the disputes are pending or whether an application to only one of them would be enough.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unnecessary to decision as facts show applications to both.

precedents.citation: The Premier Automobiles Limited v. Ramchandra Bhimayya 1

anchor.surface_text: Moreover, it is against the rules of interpretation to add words to a provision, when the provision, as it stands, is capable of a reasonable meaning which will give effect to the intention of the legislature even on the words as they stand. On the plain meaning of the proviso, it is clear that it gives the employer the power to discharge or dismiss the employee before obtaining the approval of the tribunal concerned but at the same time the protection afforded to the employee by the proviso has to remain effective. It seems to us therefore that when the proviso speaks of an application for approval of the action taken, the action taken there is the order of actual discharge or dismissal made by the employer and it is for the approval of this order that the application is to be made.

edges.explanation: Holding h1 interprets the proviso to s.33(2)(b), addressing the issue i2 of interpretation of the terms of s.33(2).
Holding on proviso requirements addresses issue on interpretation of proviso to cl.(b)

anchor.surface_text: Moreover, it is against the rules of interpretation to add words to a provision, when the provision, as it stands, is capable of a reasonable meaning which will give effect to the intention of the legislature even on the words as they stand. On the plain meaning of the proviso, it is clear that it gives the employer the power to discharge or dismiss the employee before obtaining the approval of the tribunal concerned but at the same time the protection afforded to the employee by the proviso has to remain effective. It seems to us therefore that when the proviso speaks of an application for approval of the action taken, the action taken there is the order of actual discharge or dismissal made by the employer and it is for the approval of this order that the application is to be made.

It is not disputed before us that when the proviso lays down the condition as to payment of one months wages, all that the employer is required to do in order to carry out that condition is to tender the wages to the employee. But if the employee chooses not to accept the wages, he cannot come forward and say that there has been no payment of wages to him by the employer.

If the tribunal does not approve of the action taken by the employer, the result would be that the action taken by him would fall and thereupon the workman would be deemed never to have been dismissed or discharged and would remain in the service of the employer.
s an order of dismissal or discharge before obtaining the approval of the authority companycerned and at the same time make an application for approva

edges.explanation: Holding specifying simultaneous and immediate requirements directly addresses the issue of when an application should be made under the proviso

anchor.surface_text: As we read the proviso, we are of opinion that it contemplates the three things mentioned therein, namely, (i) dismissal or discharge, (ii) payments of wages and (iii) making of ,an application for approval, to be simultaneous and to be part of the same transaction, so that the employer when he takes action under s. 33 (2) by dismissing or discharging an employee, should immediately pay him or offer to pay him wages for one month and also make an application to the tribunal for approval at the same time.

As we read the proviso, we are of opinion that it contemplates the three things mentioned therein, namely, (i) dismissal or discharge, (ii) payments of wages and (iii) making of ,an application for approval, to be simultaneous and to be part of the same transaction, so that the employer when he takes action under s. 33 (2) by dismissing or discharging an employee, should immediately pay him or offer to pay him wages for one month and also make an application to the tribunal for approval at the same time.

anchor.surface_text: The application at Meerut was received on February 3 and the application at Allahabad on February 4, 1960. In these circumstances we are of opinion that the appellant had made the application to the tribunal simultaneously and without delay on its passing the order of dismissal and its action was therefore in accordance with the proviso.
